configuratorIntro1: Quince Configurator simplifies the set-up and testing of an {{{a target='_blank' rel='noopener noreferrer' href='https://github.com/shawnbanasick/qunicy' }}} Quince {{{/a}}} project for online Q sorting. It provides guided editing of the Q sort configuration files and offers increased control over the design of the Q sort.
configPara1: The config.xml file has two sections. The first section contains the settings for the overall structure of your project. The second section includes a question generator for an (optional) questionnaire after the participant completes the Q sort.
configPara1b: <mark>Highlighted</mark> options must be customized for your project
configPara2: If you have a config.xml file from another Quince project made with this version of the configurator, you can load its data for editing by clicking the orange - 'Load config.xml Data' - button below. If you don't have a file from a previous project, you can load the default config.xml file from the settings folder, or you can create a new file by inputting all of the data yourself.
configPara3: After you have added your data, click the orange 'Save config.xml File' button below to save the information to the Quince template 'settings' folder (replacing the default file).
configDownloadXmlDescription: Save your current settings to the Quince Template files 'settings' folder and replace the 'config.xml' file
configLoadXmlDescription: Load an existing config.xml file to continue working with saved settings or to modify a previous project.
projectLinking: Link to a Second Q Sort
sortImages: Sort Images / Pictures Instead of Text Statements
imageSortDisabled: Image sorting is currently unavailable, but will be added in a future release.
unforcedSortsNotPossible: Unforced sorts will be added in a future release
areYouSure: Are you sure you want to delete this item?
enterOrPasteStatements: Enter or Paste Statements (1 statement per line)
statementInfoCard1: Previous Projects: If you want to modify statements from a previous Quince project, you can click on the orange 'Load statements.xml File' button to upload the statements.xml file.
statementInfoCard2: New Projects: If you want to create new statements, you can type them directly into the text box below, or paste statements from another file. Each statement must be on a new line.
statementInfoCard3: Save Statement File: After you have finished adding or modifying your statements, you must save the file. click the orange button at the top right side of the page and save your information as 'statements.xml' in the settings folder (replacing the default file).
htmlFormattingSubTitle: Statements can include simple HTML formatting if desired
htmlFormattingBottomTitle: Other information on HTML paired tag formatting can be found in the Config section.
uploadStatementsXmlDescriptionText: Load an existing statements.xml file to continue working with saved settings or to modify a previous project
downloadStatementsXmlDescriptionText: Save your current customizations as 'statements.xml' file and replace the file in the Quince Template files 'settings' folder
createOrEditYourQsortStatements: Create and edit your Q-sort statements
columnsLayoutSubTitle: Decide the number of statements in each column and the visual design
mapInputElementTitle: Each gray box represents one column in your project. The number at the top is the Q sort value of the column. The number in the yellow box will be the number of statements in that column. The column color (if desired) is at the bottom. The colors can be set individually by clicking on the color, or you can use the preset buttons below to use on of the default color pallets.
columnLabelsboxSubTitle: Select the appropriate preset level for your project.
sortTextInputSubTitle: Enter column headers separated by commas.
columnTextInputPlaceholder: For example: 'Very Important, Important, Neutral, Less Important, Not Important'
mapIntroText1: If you have a 'map.xml' from a previous Quince project, you can load its data for editing by clicking on the orange 'Load map.xml Data' button below to upload the file and make revisions. If you don't have a file from a previous project, you can create a new file by inputting your data below.
mapIntroText2: After you have customized the data, click the orange 'Download map.xml File' button below to save the information to the Quince template 'settings' folder (replacing the default file).
uploadMapDescription: Load an existing map.xml file to continue working with saved settings or to modify a previous project
downloadMapDescription: Save your current settings as a 'map.xml' file and replace the file in the Quince Template files 'settings' folder
noStatementsLoaded: No Statements Loaded in the Statements.xml section
loadStatementsError: Error: No statements loaded in the Statements.xml section. Please load a file or enter statements in the 'Statements' section.
allStatementsAssignedError: Error: Some statements have not been assigned to a column. Please check the number of statements in the Q-sort grid.
missingMobileColumnLabels: Error: Missing mobile column labels. Please enter the correct number of mobile column labels.
baserowIntro1: Follow this visual guide to setup a database to store the Q sort results
databaseIntroText: {{{b}}}Quince uses Baserow to store your participant data safely. {{{/b}}} {{{u}}}{{{a href='https://baserow.io/' rel='noopener noreferrer' target='_blank'}}}Baserow{{{/a}}}{{{/u}}} is an online database that follows strict privacy rules (GDPR, IPAA, and SOC2). It is a European company and their servers are located in Germany. You can read more about their policies on the {{{u}}}{{{a href='https://baserow.io/faq' rel='noopener noreferrer' target='_blank'}}}{{{strong}}}Baserow FAQ{{{/strong}}}{{{/a}}}{{{/u}}} - just click on the 'Security' section.{{{br /}}}{{{br /}}} Baserow makes it easy to create tables and manage your Q sort data through a simple interface. It's free to use for projects with less than  3,000 participants! {{{br /}}} {{{br /}}}{{{b}}}Getting started:{{{/b}}} Click the orange button below to download a file called 'baserowHeader.csv'. You'll need this file to complete your setup. Then go to Step 1 of the visual guide
baserowStep1: Visit {{{u}}}{{{a href='https://baserow.io' rel='noopener noreferrer' target='_blank'}}}{{{strong}}}Baserow.io{{{/strong}}}{{{/a}}}{{{/u}}} and create a new account by clicking on the 'Sign Up' button in the upper right corner of the page.
baserowStep2: Next, fill in the required information and click the 'Get Started' button.
baserowStep3: Click the 'Skip for now' button to bypass the data collection.
baserowStep4: Click the 'Skip for now' button to bypass the data collection.
baserowStep5: Input your first workspace name (any name is fine) and click the 'Continue' button.
baserowStep6: Click the 'Skip for now' button to skip inviting collaborators.
baserowStep7: Input your database name and click the 'Continue' button.
baserowStep9: Input a table name (any name is OK - you will delete this table later) and three row names (any text is OK), then click the 'Continue' button.
baserowStep10: Click the 'Skip for now' button to skip choosing fields
emailOnlyDescription: No database setup is needed for this option. The participant' default email client will send the data by email to the researcher.
baserowStep11: You should now delete the default table you just created. Hover your mouse over the 'Qsorts' and three vertical dots will appear on the right. Click the dots and then click 'Delete' in the dropdown selection box.
baserowStep12: Next click on the 'database1' button and a '+ New table' option will appear below it. Click on '+ New table'.
baserowStep13: In the 'Create new table' dialog box, click 'Import a CSV file', then type in the name of your project. Next, click on 'Choose CSV file' and load the CSV file (named 'baserowHeader.csv') that you downloaded when you clicked the orange button at the top of this page.
baserowStep14: The dialog box should now appear as in the image below, with 'r1', 'r2', and 'r3' in the sections with green ellipses. Click the 'Add table' button.
baserowStep15: You should now have a new table with 'r1', 'r2', and 'r3' in the header section. In the next step you'll set the access rules for the table and get the identification numbers.
baserowStep16: Click in the up/down arrows to the right of the workspace name ('participantData1' in the image) and then click on 'My settings'.
baserowStep17: Next, click on the 'Database tokens' on the left side of the Settings dialog box. Then, click 'Create token'. Click on the 'read', 'update', and 'delete' switches to turn them off. Next, click on 'show databases'. Take note of the {{{b}}}database ID number{{{/b}}}. You'll need it for setup of the config.xml file in the next section.
baserowStep18: Click on the three dots and then copy the {{{b}}}database 'Token'{{{/b}}}. Take note of this number - you'll need it for setup of the config.xml file in the next section.
setupCompleteMessage: Congratulations! You have successfully completed the Baserow database setup process. Your database is now ready for data collection.
languageSubtitle: User Interface Language Settings for Desktop and Mobile
languageIntroText1: If you have a language.xml file from another Quince project, you can load its settings into the Configurator by clicking the orange Load 'language.xml' File button below.
languageIntroText2: If you have a language.xml file from another Quince project, you can load it into the Configurator by clicking the orange 'Load 'language.xml' File Data' button below. If you don't have a file from a previous project, you can load the default English settings by clicking the section buttons, or you can create a new file by inputting all of the data yourself.
languageIntroText3: The 'Use Defaults' button will insert the default text into all of the input boxes in that section. The 'Clear Section' button will clear all of the input boxes in that section. The 'Images' buttons give hints about the location of the text in the application.
languageIntroText4: Simple text formatting is available here by using tags before and after the text to be modified. Simple formatting options include bold, italics, yellow highlighting, and underline.
languageIntroText5:
A new line can be inserted using a single break tag
, and an open line between text can be created by using two break tags

.
languageIntroText6: A web page link can be inserted by using this pattern:
languageIntroText8: Font size can be adjusted by using this pattern:
languageIntroText10: Complex HTML layouts are possible for the Welcome message, Submit Data text, Goodbye message, and pop-up modal texts. In-line CSS styling can be used to modify the HTML elements.
languageIntroText11: You can use CodePen to interactively develop complex layouts. In CodePen, click on the "Start Coding" button on the top left side of the page, then put your code in the "HTML" box on the left. When you are happy with the layout, copy and paste the HTML code from CodePen into the input boxes below.
languageIntroText16: Vertical and horizontal centering for pages
languageIntroText17: Vertical and horizontal centering for messages
languageIntroText18b: See the default text below for more HTML examples
languageIntroText19: Highlighted options must be customized for your project. By default only the sections of the user interface with these highlighted options are shown. However, any part of the user interface language change be changed. Click on the 'All Settings' button above to see all of the options.
languageIntroText20: When you have finished adding your language data, click the orange 'Download language.xml File' button below, save the file to the settings folder, and replace the default file.
uploadLanguageXml: Upload an existing language XML file to load your text configuration
downloadLanguageXml: Download your current language configuration as an XML file
multiScreenConfigurationsSubTitle: Configure settings that apply to multiple screens
accessAndConsentSubTitle: Configure access control and consent page content
welcomeScreensSubTitle: Configure welcome messages for desktop and mobile
presortConfigurationSubTitle: Set up pre-sorting instructions and interface
refinementProcessSubTitle: Configure the statement refinement and evaluation phase
sortingInterfaceSubTitle: Configure the main Q sorting interface
surveyConfigurationSubTitle: Set up additional survey question and forms
submissionAndCompletionSubTitle: Configure submission process and completion messages
errorsAndLinkingSubTitle: Configure error messages and project linking
mobileTextSizeAdjustmentButtonText: Mobile Text Size Adjustment Button Text
mobileViewAreaSizeButtonText: Mobile View Area Size Button Text
numStatementsToSelect: Number of Statements to Select Text
currentlySelectedNumber: Number of Statements Currently Selected Text
initialInstructionPart3: Another Set of Statements is Displayed
moveTopMobileButtonOK: Move All to Top Modal OK Button Text
mobileThinScrollBottomModalHead: Must Scroll to Bottom of List Modal Title
mobileThinScrollBottomModalText: Must Scroll to Bottom of List Modal Text
mobileSortScrollBottomModalHead: Must Scroll to Bottom of List Modal Title
mobileSortScrollBottomModalText: Must Scroll to Bottom of List Modal Text
clipboardEmail: Copy Email Address to Clipboard Button Text
clipboardResults: Copy Results to Clipboard Button Text
processResultsText: After finishing your Q study, use this page to create a results report and files for analysis of your Q sort data
loadBaserowButtonOverText: Then, Load your Baserow results CSV file first.
beginExportProcess: First load your project's settings files (config.xml, statements.xml, map.xml, and language.xml) into the Configurator tabs 2-6. Then, use the Visual Guide below to download your results from Baserow. Next, load that results file using the orange button below to begin the results export process
fileStatus: Information from your project's settings files is required. Click on tabs 2, 3, 4, and 5 at the top of the page to load your settings files and then return to this page to continue the process.
preUploadResultsFileText: Please load your Baserow CSV data file to begin the results export process
exportSubtitlePqmethod: Download results report and {{{b}}}{{{u}}}{{{a target='_blank' rel='noopener noreferrer' className='text-[#0c8492]' href='http://schmolck.org/qmethod/'}}}PQMethod{{{/a}}}{{{/u}}}{{{/b}}} data files for analysis
exportSubtitleKade: Download results report and {{{b}}}{{{u}}}{{{a target='_blank' rel='noopener noreferrer' className='text-[#0c8492]' href='https://github.com/shawnbanasick/kade'}}}KADE{{{/a}}}{{{/u}}}{{{/b}}} ZIP file for data analysis
kadeButtonSubLabel: All data in a single Zip File
pqmethodButtonSubLabel: PQMethod compatible data and statement files
identifierSelectionSubTitle: Choose how participants are identified in the exported files
exportStep1: Log into your Baserow account. Then, navigate to the table you want to export by clicking on the database names on the left side of the page. Hover your mouse over the table name and click on the three vertical dots that are displayed.
exportStep3: In the dialog box that appears, click on the dropdown selection to choose the 'Column separator'.
exportStep4: Select 'record separator', and then click the 'Export' button.
exportStep5: After processing for a few moments, Baserow will display a 'Download' button. Click it to download your data.
exportSuccess2: Congratulations! Your database file is now ready to upload using the orange button at the top of this page.
downloadResultsAndAnalysis: Download Results and Analysis Data Files
netlifyIntro1: Follow this visual guide to create a web page for your Q sort project
netlifyIntroText: {{{b}}}Quince uses Netlify to host your project on the web. {{{/b}}} {{{u}}}{{{a href='https://www.netlify.com/' rel='noopener noreferrer' target='_blank'}}}Netlify{{{/a}}}{{{/u}}} is a well-known web hosting company that has a free tier for small sites. You don't need any programming skills to use it.{{{br /}}}{{{br /}}}This guide will show you how to {{{b}}}setup a new project{{{/b}}} or {{{b}}}update an existing project{{{/b}}} (see step 12).
netlifyStep1: Visit {{{u}}}{{{a href='https://www.netlify.com/' rel='noopener noreferrer' target='_blank'}}}{{{strong}}}Netlify{{{/strong}}}{{{/a}}}{{{/u}}} and create a new account by clicking on the 'Sign Up' button at the top of the page.
netlifyStep2: Next, click on the 'Sign up with email' link.
netlifyStep3: Enter your Email and Password information, and click the 'Sign up' button.
netlifyStep5: On the 'Deploy your first project' box, click on 'Skip this step for now'.
netlifyStep6: On the 'Add your project to Netlify' dialog box, look for the 'deploy manually' area. Click on the 'browse to upload' link and select your Quince project's {{{b}}}FOLDER{{{/b}}} (not the individual files).
netlifyStep7: Netlify will now have generated your project's web page, but it has a randomly assigned name. To change it, click on the 'View project' button.
netlifyStep8: Then click on 'Project configuration' on the left side of the page.
netlifyStep9: Click on the 'Change project name' button.
netlifyStep10: Input your project's name, and then click the 'Save' button.
netlifyStep11: Netlify should now show your project's new URL using the project name. Your project is now available on the web with this URL address.
netlifyStep12: If you want to {{{b}}}UPDATE{{{/b}}} your project after making a change with the Configurator, login to your Netlify account and click on your project's name. Your project's name should be at the top of the page. Then, click on 'Deploys' on the left side of the page.
netlifyStep13: In the 'Deploys' box, click on the 'browse to upload' link and select your project's {{{b}}}FOLDER{{{/b}}}. In a few minutes your project will be updated on the web.
netlifySetupCompleteMessage: Congratulations! You have successfully setup your project on the web. Your website is now ready for use.
